title: Team Semicolon
text:
This is our project webpage.
Please stay tuned to follow our project activities.
This is our template.

Team Members

Duygu Alsan
Kubilay Usta
Ahmet Şangüder
Ahmet Furkan Gökcük
Fikret Berkay Dilaver



Project Topic
We did a study looking at how many people in Turkey took their own lives from 2002 to 2022. We wanted to understand if the increase in stress and the more news about suicide are making it seem like more people are doing it, or if there’s a real increase in suicides.
In our data set, we have details about when people did suicide, why they did it, how old they were, and if they were male or female. This data helps us see the patterns and changes in suicide rates over the twenty years. We can use this data to understand why people do this and how we can help them better.




 Back to top

title: Analysis
text:
We used the bar plot method to compare suicides by gender regardless of age and reason. You can find the graph and the code we used below.


Code
library(tidyverse) 
library(dslabs)
library(readxl)
data1 <- read_excel("C:/Users/kubil/Desktop/veri seti.xls")
save(data1, file = "semicolon.RData")




Code
filtered_data_male <- filter(data1, Sex == "Male", `Age group`=="Total")
male = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_male$Total))
filtered_data_female <- filter(data1, Sex == "Female", `Age group`=="Total")
female = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_female$Total))
data <- c(male,female)
barplot(data, names.arg = c("Male","Female"), col = "skyblue", main = "Number of Suicides by Gender", xlab = "Sex", ylab = "Total")





-From this graph, we can observe that men are more prone to suicide compared to women.



We used the bar plot method to compare suicides by age groups regardless of gender and reason. You can find the graph and the code we used below.


Code
filtered_data_1 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="<15", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_2 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="15-19", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_3 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="20-24", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_4 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="25-29", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_5 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="30-34", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_6 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="35-39", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_7 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="40-44", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_8 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="45-49", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_9 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="50-54", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_10 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="55-59", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_11 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="60-64", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_12 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="65-69", Sex == "Total")
filtered_data_13 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="75 +", Sex == "Total")
age1 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_1$Total))
age2 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_2$Total))
age3 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_3$Total))
age4 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_4$Total))
age5 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_5$Total))
age6 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_6$Total))
age7 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_7$Total))
age8 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_8$Total))
age9 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_9$Total))
age10 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_10$Total))
age11 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_11$Total))
age12 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_12$Total))
age13 = sum(as.numeric(filtered_data_13$Total))
data = c(age1,age2,age3,age4,age5,age6,age7,age8,age9,age10,age11,age12,age13)
barplot(data, names.arg = c("<15","15-19","20-24","25-29","30-34","35-39","40-44","45-49","50-54","55-59","60-64","65-69","75 +"), col = "red", main = "Number of Suicides by Age Group", xlab = "Age Group", ylab = "Total")





When looking at this graph, we observe that suicides are most common among young adults aged 20-24. We can say that as age progresses beyond 25, suicide rates tend to decrease. Another interesting result is that the age groups with the lowest suicide rates are children and the elderly.

year1 = sum(as.numeric(ffiltered_data_1$Total))

year13 = sum(as.numeric(ffiltered_data_13$Total))

data = c(year1,year2,year3,year4,year5,year6,year7,year8,year9,year10,year11,year12,year13,year14,year15,year16,year17,year18,year19,year20,year21)
barplot(data, names.arg = c("2002","2003","2004","2005","2006","2007","2008","2009","2010","2011","2012","2013","2014","2015","2016","2017","2018","2019","2020","2021","2022"), col = "yellow", main = "Number of Suicides by Year", xlab = "Year", ylab = "Total")







Code
fffiltered_data_1 <- filter(data1,`Age group`=="Total", Sex == "Total")
cause1 = sum(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$Illness))
cause2 = sum(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$`Family incompatibility`))
cause3 = sum(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$`Economic problems`))
cause4 = sum(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$`Business failure`))
cause5 = sum(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$`Emotional relationship and not marrying the person wanted`))
cause6 = sum(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$`Educational failure`))
cause7 = sum(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$Other))
unknown <- ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$Unknown)),0,as.numeric(fffiltered_data_1$Unknown))
cause8 = sum(unknown)
data = c(cause1,cause2,cause3,cause4,cause5,cause6,cause7,cause8)




Code
barplot(data, names.arg = c("Illness","Family","Economy","Business","Emotional","Educational","Other","Unknown"), col = "brown", main = "Number of Suicides by Reason", xlab = "Suicide Reason", ylab = "Total",cex.names=0.72)

title: Data
text:
Data source: TUIK


Code
library(readxl)
library(tidyverse)
library(rvest)
library(stringr)
library(knitr)
data1 <- read_excel("C:/Users/kubil/Desktop/veri seti.xls")
save(data1, file = "semicolon.RData")


Download the data set : semicolon.RData

title: Data
text:
Why this data set?
We choose this data set based on this reasons:

There are so many observations in this data set
Data has been divided into multiple categories
Source of the data set is reliable (TUİK)
Data set didn’t need any preprocessing

title: Data
section: What are the categories of this data set?
text:
What are the categories of this data set?
The reasons for suicides in this dataset are categorized into eight groups:

Illness
Family incompatibility
Economic problems
Business failure
Emotional relationships and not marrying the person wanted
Educational failure
Other
Unknown.

title: Data
section: What are the age groups of this data set?
text:
What are the age groups of this data set?
Age groups are classified as :

<15
15-19
20-24
25-29
30-34
35-39
40-44
45-49
50-54
55-59
60-64
65-69
70-74
+75.

title: Data
text:
What is our aim?
By leveraging this dataset, we aim to answer the following questions:

Suicide rates by gender regardless of age and reason
Suicide rates by age regardless of gender and reason
Suicide rates by reasons regardless of age and gender
The most observed reason for suicides for females/males
The most observed reason for suicides for teenagers

By obtaining answers to these questions, we can understand how to approach preventing suicides for different age groups and genders.
